p: MR can also be used to untangle on-target and off-target drug effects. Walker et al. postulated that angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors may act through a different mechanism, since no link was found between Alzheimerâ€™s disease risk and systolic blood pressure or other antihypertensives ( Walker et al., 2019 ). This principle has been illustrated in cardiometabolic disease, building on observations that statin therapy is associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus ( Sattar et al., 2009 ). Using SNPs in the HMG-CoA reductase gene HMGCR, which encodes the target for statins, an MR study showed that the raised diabetes risk is an on-target effect ( Swerdlow et al., 2015 ). Likewise, if MR evidence suggests that a side effect is an off-target effect, this could encourage the development of a drug with more specificity ( Evans and Davey Smith, 2015).
